case_name: Partners of M/s. Navinchandra Co. v. The respondent mills

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 78 of 1954 is an appeal by the plaintiffs against the decree passed by the Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 78 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 17, 1950, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 642 of 1949, arising out

facts.text: Bombay High Court passed judgment and decree dated April 17, 1950 in Appeal No. 642 of 1949 dismissing the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 17, 1950, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 642 of 1949, arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 30, 1949, of the

facts.text: Trial court (Court of Civil Judge, Senior Division, Ahmedabad) decreed the plaintiffs' claim on July 30, 1949 in Suit No. 10 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 17, 1950, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 642 of 1949, arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 30, 1949, of the Court of Civil Judge, Senior Division, Ahmedabad in Suit No. 10 of 1946.

facts.text: Appellants filed the suit on January 9, 1946 claiming Rs. 1,52,334-8-9 as damages for breach of contract.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants filed the present suit on January 9, 1946, claiming damages to the extent of Rs. 1,52,334-8-9 with interest and companys.

facts.text: Appellants are partners of M/s. Navinchandra Co.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the partners of M S. Navinchandra Co. This partnership had placed an order with the respondent for 251 bales of printed chints

facts.text: Appellants placed order with respondent for 251 bales of printed chints on or about July 4, 1942, accepted by respondent's letters dated July 11 and July 20, 1942, delivery in September and October 1942.

anchor.surface_text: This partnership had placed an order with the respondent for 251 bales of printed chints on or about July 4, 1942, and the said order had been accepted by the respondent by its letters dated July 1 1 and July 20, 1942. The delivery period for the said goods was fixed for the months of September and October, 1942.

facts.text: Appellants placed another order for 31 bales of printed chints on July 24, 1942, accepted by respondent on July 25, 1942, delivery in October 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Another order was placed by the appellants with the respondent for 31 bales of printed chints on July 24, 1942, and this order was accepted by the respondent on July 25, 1942. The delivery of these goods was to be given in the month of October 1942.

facts.text: Workers in respondent's mills went on strike on August 9, 1942 in sympathy with Quit India movement.

anchor.surface_text: On August 9, 1942, the workers in the respondent mills went on strike in sympathy with the Quit-India, movement which had then companymenced.

facts.text: Respondent wrote to appellants on August 15, 1942 stating delivery time of pending contracts extended automatically for period working stopped and until normal state of affairs recurred.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence, the respondent wrote to the appellants firm on August 15, 1942, and stated that, in view of the strike and the political situation, the delivery time of all the pending companytracts should be automatically understood as extended for the period the working of the mills was stopped and until the numbermal state of affairs recurred.

facts.text: Strike ended and mills resumed working on November 22, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The strike came to an end and the mills resumed working on November 22, 1942.

facts.text: On December 5, 1942, Keshavlal and Ratilal approached Jasubhai for delivery of goods; he told them contracts were void.

anchor.surface_text: On December 5, 1942, Jasubhai, who was then in charge of the management of the mills was approached by the appellants, Keshavlal and Ratilal, for obtaining delivery of the goods. He, however, told them that the appellants companytracts were void and so numberdelivery companyld be claimed or given.

facts.text: Jasubhai wrote to appellants on December 6, 1942 informing contracts null and void.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1942, the said Jasubhai wrote to the appellants informing them that their companytracts were number binding on the mills as they were null and void.

facts.text: Managing agency of mills fell to Jasubhai and Babubhai on September 18, 1942 as result of compromise between Chinubhai and brothers.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at this stage that, when the companytracts were made between the appellants and the respondent, Chinubhai Lalbhai was in charge of the managing agency of the mills. Subsequently, on September 18, 1942, as a result of the companypromise between Chinubhai and his brothers Jasubhai and Babubhai, this managing agency of the mills fell to the share of Jasubhai and Babubhai.

facts.text: Appellants wrote to respondent on December 17, 1942 stating respondent bound to deliver due to extension letter of August 15, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: On December 17, 1942, the appellants wrote to the respondent that, as the respondent had extended the time of delivery of all goods by its letter dated August 15, 1942, the respondent was bound to deliver the companytracted goods and that if the respondent did number do so, the appellants would be companypelled to take legal proceedings against the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent replied on December 20, 1942 repeating contentions.

anchor.surface_text: In reply, the respondent repeated its earlier companytentions by its letter dated December 20, 1942.

facts.text: Appellants formally demanded delivery in January and February 1943; no compliance.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then formally demanded the delivery of goods in January and again in February 1943, and, since the demand was number companyplied with, the appellants filed the present suit on January 9, 1946,

facts.text: Respondent resisted suit claiming no agreement on extension of time, suit barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by the respondent on several grounds. In particular, the respondent urged that there was numberagreement between the parties with regard to the extension of time and so the suit was barred by limitation.

facts.text: Trial judge found in favour of appellants on extension of time and limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge framed several issues with two of which the present appeal is companycerned. These two issues related to the question of extension of time for the performance of the companytract and the plea of limitation. On both these points, the learned judge found in favour of the appellants.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held no reliable acceptance of extension, conduct did not show acceptance, and extension agreement vague and uncertain; suit barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court have held that the oral evidence led by the appellants to show the acceptance of the respondents proposal for the extension of time companyld number be treated as true or reliable. They also rejected the appellants case on the ground that the companyduct of the appellants subsequent to the stoppage of the respondents mills did number show acceptance of the respondents proposal for extension of time. Besides, in the opinion of the High Court, even if acceptance had been proved, it was number possible to ascribe any certain or definite meaning to the words used by the respondent in its letter dated August 15, 1942  Ex. P. 78  , and so this agreement to extend time was void since it wag vague and uncertain.

facts.text: Supreme Court found oral evidence of Ratilal and Keshavlal on acceptance of extension true and conduct consistent with acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, we are disposed to take the view that the evidence given by Ratilal and Keshavlal is true. Besides, the companyduct of the parties also points to the same companyclusion.

facts.text: Supreme Court held agreement to extend time vague and uncertain due to second condition 'till normal state of affairs recurred', void under s.29 Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the learned Judges of the High Court were right in companying to the companyclusion that the companyditions mentioned by the respondent in its letter asking for extension of time were so vague and uncertain that it is number possible to ascertain definitely the period for which- the time for the performance of the companytract was really intended to be extended.

facts.text: Ratilal stated he met Chinubhai 4-5 days after August 15, 1942 letter and orally accepted extension.

anchor.surface_text: Ratilal P. W. I stated that, four or five days after this letter was received, he went to Ahmedabad where he met and companysulted Keshavlal. Then he saw Chinubhai at the mills and told him that he accepted the extension of time as per the said letter.

facts.text: No demand for delivery made by appellants during original delivery period.

anchor.surface_text: If the period for the delivery of the goods had number been extended by mutual companysent, we would numbermally have expected the appellants to make a demand for delivery of the goods on due dates as fixed under the original companytracts. It is companyceded that numbersuch demand was made.

facts.text: Political agitation and Quit India movement affected Ahmedabad in 1942; common knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon knowledge that, at the material time, the whole companyntry in general and the city of Ahmedabad in particular was in the grip of a very serious political agitation and numberody companyld anticipate how long the strike resulting from the said, agitation would last.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal; parties to bear own costs throughout.

anchor.surface_text: The result is we companyfirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the dismissal of the present appeal. We are, however, free to state that we have reached this companyclusion with some reluctance ... Under these circumstances we think the fair order as to companyts would be that parties should bear their own companyts throughout.

holdings.text: The evidence given by Ratilal and Keshavlal regarding oral acceptance of the extension proposal is true, corroborated by conduct of the parties.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, we are disposed to take the view that the evidence given by Ratilal and Keshavlal is true. Besides, the conduct of the parties also points to the same conclusion. If the period for the delivery of the goods had not been extended by mutual consent, we would normally have expected the appellants to make a demand for delivery of the goods on due dates as fixed under the original contracts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witness testimony consistent with probabilities, no reason to disbelieve, corroborated by lack of demand during original period and demand post-reopening; sauda books inference unsafe.

holdings.text: Under s.63 of the Indian Contract Act, extension of time requires mutual assent between buyer and seller, provable by oral evidence or conduct.

anchor.surface_text: The true legal position in regard to the extension of time for the performance of a contract is quite clear under s. 63 of the Indian Contract Act. Every promise, as the section provides, may extend time for the performance of the contract. The question as to how extension of time may be agreed upon by the parties has been the subject-matter of some argument at the Bar in the present appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unilateral extension invalid; must be bilateral agreement, flexible proof methods suffice.

holdings.text: The conditions in the respondent's letter dated August 15, 1942, especially 'till the normal state of affairs recurred', are vague and uncertain.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the learned Judges of the High Court were right in coming to the conclusion that the conditions mentioned by the respondent in its letter asking for extension of time were so vague and uncertain that it is not possible to ascertain definitely the period for which- the time for the performance of the contract was really intended to be extended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second condition indefinable (political/normal mill operations unpredictable); judicial notice of Quit India uncertainty; plaint assumes only strike period.

holdings.text: Agreement for extension of time is void under s.29 of the Indian Contract Act due to vagueness and uncertainty.

anchor.surface_text: In such a case, the agreement for extension must be held to be vague and uncertain and as such void under s. 29 of the Indian Contract Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Terms lack definite meaning ascertainable by court; distinguished Nicolene (severable meaningless clause) as both conditions integral to proposal.

holdings.text: Plea of vagueness/uncertainty, being pure question of law based on document construction, can be raised for first time in appeal under O.41 r.2 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: After all, the plea raised is a plea of law based solely upon the construction of the letter which is the basis of the case for the extension of time for the performance of the contract and so it was competent to the appeal court to allow such a plea to be raised under O. 41, r. 2, of the Code of Civil Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No new facts required; appellate power to entertain.

holdings.text: No extrinsic evidence admissible to remove vagueness/uncertainty in document under s.93 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: If, on a fair construction, the condition mentioned in the document is held to be vague or uncertain, no evidence can be admitted to remove the said vagueness or uncertainty. The provisions of s. 93 of the Indian Evidence Act are clear on this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language alone governs; extrinsic aid would rewrite contract.

holdings.text: Absence of valid extension renders suit barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The result is we confirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the dismissal of the present appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid extension means original delivery period governs limitation.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed; parties to bear own costs throughout.

anchor.surface_text: The result is we confirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the dismissal of the present appeal. We are, however, free to state that we have reached this conclusion with some reluctance ... Under these circumstances we think the fair order as to costs would be that parties should bear their own costs throughout.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reluctance due to respondent's lack of bona fides but technical success on new plea justifies no costs.

anchor.surface_text: Nicolene Ld. v. Simmonds 1 . In that case, a companytract for the sale of a quantity of reinforcing steel bars was expressed as subject to the usual companyditions of acceptance . The seller repudiated the companytract whereupon the buyers claimed and were awarded by the trial judge damages for the breach of companytract. On appeal, the seller companytended that the companytract was number companycluded there being numberconsensus ad item in regard to the companyditions of acceptance. It was held that, there being numberusual companyditions of acceptance , the companydition was meaningless and should be ignored, and that the companytract was companyplete and enforceable.

precedents.cited_proposition: A vague and uncertain clause that is meaningless and severable can be ignored without impairing the contract
precedents.cited_holding: the condition was meaningless and should be ignored, and the contract was complete and enforceable

precedents.citation: Scammel G. And Nephew, Ld. v. Ouston H. C. And J. 0. 1

anchor.surface_text: Scammel G. And Nephew, Ld. v. Ouston H. C. And J. 0. 1 . In this case, the respondent had agreed to purchase from the appellant a new motor-van but stipulated that this order was given on the understanding that the balance of purchase price can be had on the hire-purchase terms over a. period of two years. The House of Lords held that the clause as to hire-purchase terms was so vague that numberprecise meaning companyld be attributed to it and companysequently there was numberenforceable companytract between the parties.

precedents.cited_proposition: Vague and uncertain terms prevent the formation of an enforceable contract
precedents.cited_holding: the clause as to hire-purchase terms was so vague that no precise meaning could be attributed to it and consequently there was no enforceable contract

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, we are disposed to take the view that the evidence given by Ratilal and Keshavlal is true. Besides, the conduct of the parties also points to the same conclusion. If the period for the delivery of the goods had not been extended by mutual consent, we would normally have expected the appellants to make a demand for delivery of the goods on due dates as fixed under the original contracts.
The result is we confirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the

anchor.surface_text: The true legal position in regard to the extension of time for the performance of a contract is quite clear under s. 63 of the Indian Contract Act. Every promise, as the section provides, may extend time for the performance of the contract. The question as to how extension of time may be agreed upon by the parties has been the subject-matter of some argument at the Bar in the present appeal.
The result is we confirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the learned Judges of the High Court were right in coming to the conclusion that the conditions mentioned by the respondent in its letter asking for extension of time were so vague and uncertain that it is not possible to ascertain definitely the period for which- the time for the performance of the contract was really intended to be extended.
The result is we confirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the

anchor.surface_text: After all, the plea raised is a plea of law based solely upon the construction of the letter which is the basis of the case for the extension of time for the performance of the contract and so it was competent to the appeal court to allow such a plea to be raised under O. 41, r. 2, of the Code of Civil Procedure.
The result is we confirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the

edges.explanation: Holding h6 (no extrinsic evidence to remove vagueness) supports holding h5 (vagueness plea is pure question of law on document construction).

anchor.surface_text: If, on a fair construction, the condition mentioned in the document is held to be vague or uncertain, no evidence can be admitted to remove the said vagueness or uncertainty. The provisions of s. 93 of the Indian Evidence Act are clear on this point.
The result is we confirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the
